channel.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
channel.description:
Runescape Classic Sprite Viewer v3.0
Written in: VB6 (Visual basic 6)
Credits, In program
This is just a simple sprite viewer, overlaying program I made as a small self-project, please post feedback on ideas ect. It comes with all sprites and data, no need to use the original sprite editors.
Keep in mind, its only a viewer, not editor, so really it's probably pointless to any of you, but I wanted to share it anyway :)
Known bugs/Problems, I made special conditions for certain items, like gloves, chain, boots ect as they need legs/torsos behind them, but.. You cant wear a chain and gloves together, or a robe and gloves ect, no big deal, It'd take way to much time to edit the code so that works.
Crossbows are ment to be in the right hand box, not left, and bows don't render properly because they dont have fighting animations, Ur probably thinking why didn't I fix this before i posted, but I only just found out from a friend, and it's actually quite alot of code to work around.
Also, If someone could reply, On how the sprites are rendered to the North west, West and South west, because you cant just flip the opposites, example, if you flip the sprite facing east, the weapon / shield remains in the same place, Like.. the sword will go from the right hand to the left hand, in rsc it switches hands, have no idea how that works because theres no sprites for them, so it must be all custom
Screenshot:
[img]http://i880.photobucket.com/albums/ac9/kirkesp/screenshotv3.jpg[/img]
Download Link: http://uppit.com/1udrepkv7phn/Sprite_Viewer_v3.0.zip

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @dimebagx dimebagx
item.description:
@dimebagx wrote:

Zilent:

The sprites are made of a 25 byte header followed by the pixel data represented by an integer array. The culmination of sprites are then put into a zip archive for deployment. In order to properly register them with the RSCD client you’ll need to either explicitly extend the load ranges or load them individually from within the code in the media loading method.

Nice

If you don’t mind could you please take a look at my sprite topic under client help,
You seem to be really familiar with sprites

Read full topic

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @Zilent Zilent
item.description:
@Zilent wrote:

The sprites are made of a 25 byte header followed by the pixel data represented by an integer array. The culmination of sprites are then put into a zip archive for deployment. In order to properly register them with the RSCD client you’ll need to either explicitly extend the load ranges or load them individually from within the code in the media loading method.

Read full topic

item.description:

Sprites.rscd contains the files,
each file seperates into the .png and the .spr

Im pretty sure the spr’s don’t contain the pngs

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @Z_Prototype Z Prototype
item.description:
@Z_Prototype wrote:

Correction : Spr files do indeed contain a png file. I strongly suggest you have a good go with the sprite editor, good practise and it will hopefully answer any of your questions. Make sure you actually create an spr file and go through the process of adding it to the sprites.rscd

Read full topic

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @dimebagx dimebagx
item.description:
@dimebagx wrote:

Okay yeah I get it now,
Im not completely familiar (but will look into now) is the .spr files,
Afaik the images aren’t stored inside the spr files, theres an image, and spr file for it (seperate folders)
Correct me if im wrong.

I’ll whip up the sprite editor exactly how the original is for now,
and then look at implementing new functions

Read full topic

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @Z_Prototype Z Prototype
item.description:
@Z_Prototype wrote:

Okay, the color black (Pure Black) is invisible in-game. This means that most sprites have a black background behind them. I made 15 sprites with their background filled with black. The problem was that it wasn’t perfect black. That meant every sprite had box of black around them. I think edited every image file with paint and changed the fill color (or background) color to perfect black. With that done I needed to turn all the image files (png) into spr files that rsc uses. Now because of this I also had to do all the values for them again. That’s one heck of a lot of typing.

If you could make a option to simply replace the chosen spr file’s image to a chosen png file it would be helpful.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @dimebagx dimebagx
item.description:
@dimebagx wrote:

It made sense to what I thought you ment

I know how to use it, but I don’t understand what your trying to say, i’ll make a fancy sprite editor with extra functions,

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @dimebagx dimebagx
item.description:
@dimebagx wrote:

[quote=“Z Prototype, post:16, topic:343420”]Not always, for instance I made and easy enough mistake a couple of days ago. I thought the color I was using was pure black but it turned out to be only a couple of digits off. This resulted in 15 of my images having a black solid square around them, not very good. In that case I just wanted to change the background color of my objects without having to set the values for 15 sprites again.
So, in the case of editing the same images this would be incredibly helpful and save me and other people a lot of time. I’m guessing from what a great program you have made that this wouldn’t be very complex. It’s simple swapping images. Hope you give it go :D[/quote]

Don’t fully understand what your trying to say, im not too familiar with the sprite editor, but in terms of changing the background colour, or any same colour for that matter to another, you’d use getpixel and setpixel

Or use paint.net and use the recolouring tool with a tollerence of 0 (:

But sure, id be more than happy to make something that the community can use , just need a lil more detail,
If you mean editing the “original” sprites, like drawing over them ect, this can be done, but I wouldn’t reccomend it, i’d rather use a paint program to draw sprites

Read full topic

item.title: [UPDATE] Sprite Viewer 3.0
item.dc:creator: @Z_Prototype Z Prototype
item.description:
@Z_Prototype wrote:

Not always, for instance I made and easy enough mistake a couple of days ago. I thought the color I was using was pure black but it turned out to be only a couple of digits off. This resulted in 15 of my images having a black solid square around them, not very good. In that case I just wanted to change the background color of my objects without having to set the values for 15 sprites again.

So, in the case of editing the same images this would be incredibly helpful and save me and other people a lot of time. I’m guessing from what a great program you have made that this wouldn’t be very complex. It’s simple swapping images. Hope you give it go

Read full topic
